physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry (Monroe)” are written in pencil at the top. The other pages have, typed, H.M. with the corresponding page number in the top left corner, and the date (2/17/16) in the top right corner. On the third page, there is faint text on the page near the top. The text is large and mirrored on the opposite side of the page, perhaps written on the other side? It reads, “BERKSHIRE LINEN U.S.A.”.

div.p: Your letter has just come. In regard to the Anthology, I supposed of course that you were only taking poems that had appeared in your magazine, and I was therefore only chooding from among the things of mine which you have published. As to your taking "Patterns," I am quite willing, and I am sure Margaret Anderson will be; but it has already been extensively quoted, and we are putting it in our Imagist Anthology. I suppose you would not consider the "Bombardment." That was in last year's Imagist Anthology, and also in Braithwaite's <title key=" " level="m" >book. As a matter of fact, I think it is rather a good thing from the point of view of the public, to keep dinning one poem at them, for then they get used to it and it gets into the current coin of the language. So if you wish to include "Patterns" and at the same time will be so kind as to put in "e;Red Slippers," as I should like to show some of my "polyphonic," I shall be quite satisfied.

Of course, I do not want you to not like the things you put in of mine, any more than I want not to like them myself. I realized why you put in “Apology” and “A Blockhead,” but it seemed to me that “Apology” alone was enough; but if you particularly want "A Blockhead," I have no objection; so that nos my contribution to the Anthology will consist of: "Patterns," "Red Slippers,""The Coal Picker," "Apology," "The Painter on Silk," "The Bungler," "A Gift," "Aliens," "The Back Bay Fens" (this in your list appears as "Fenway Park," but I find that "Fenway Park" is a base-ball park, so please change it to "The Back Bay Fens"), "May Evening in Central Park," "Solitaire," "A Lady," and "Venus Transiens," –with or without "A Blockhead," as you see fit.

Now about "Off the Turnpike." Your suggestion to shorten it does not meet with my approval. I am afraid the poem must stand as it is.
Mrs. Aldis is to give it as a play (together with another poem of the same series called "The Grocery," which has just been accepted by the "Masses") sometime this Spring. Now here is the difficult – I do not see why you should pay me bargain rates. You have the same number of pages in the issue, anway. Why, because you have to pay the rate of those pages to one person, should you pay any less than if you had to pay ten? It really seems to me that you might pay me the regulation rates. And here is another thing: hitherto I have always appeared twice a year in "Poetry," and that seems to me about right, It certainly does not err on the side of too frequent an appearance. Now you have not had anything of mine in the magazines since September, and if you keep me waiting until July or August, it is practically a year. Also I think it would be to your advantage to have the poem on Mrs. Aldis's programmes put down as having appeared in your paper, as "The Grocery" will be put down as having appeared in the "Masses." Louis Untermeyer writes me that the editors of the "Masses" like the poem so much that they are keeping other manuscripts waiting, in order to publish it immediately, an that it is possible that they may publish it next month; and that is in a paper where I am only just beginning to appear, whereas you, who have always published me, want to hold me back six months before putting me in.

As I told you, I am going to Chicago on the 19th of March. I hope I shall see you at the Little Theatre that night, but I shall telephone you when I strike the town, because of course the lecture is incidental – what I really want to do is to talk over these things with you. We may keep the question of "Off the Turnpike" to be discussed
cussed when I see you. As for the Anthology, I shall be quite satisfied with the arrangement made above, if that suits you, and from your letter I think it will. So go ahead and do it on that basis.

I never meant to accuse you of underhandedness in regard to Mrs. Freer's article. After reading my defence of you in the "Poetry Journal" (which, by the way, you do not mention, and I suppose you do not like it), you will see that I have said that you were scrupulously honest as an editor. I did not consider that in using the blue pencil on my article, as I thought you had done, you were dishonest, merely editorial; but I have already apologized for that, and you may be quite sure that, however annoyed we get at each other in the course of business (and I think in a mild way that is inevitable), I know you to be as truthful and honest as the Rock of Ages, one of the most so of anybody I have ever seen, and I cordially admire all you have done, and are doing, for the cause of poetry, even if at the same time I do not think you quite rate me at my true valuation. There is honesty for you!
